title: 114_hr1005
content: The "Renewable Energy Jobs Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes an Alternative Energy Training and Employment Program. The "Renewable Energy Jobs Act" establishes a pilot program for competitive grants to train individuals in renewable energy and energy efficiency industries. Grants will be awarded to the top five states with the highest alternative energy power capacity, based on wind, solar, and geothermal facilities. States must submit applications with evidence of their installed alternative energy power capacity. The curr_chunk describes how funds will be used to establish a program for skills training in renewable energy and energy efficiency industries. It also mentions the State's option to coordinate with workforce investment boards and industry councils for program implementation. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for grant recipients to provide skills training and on-the-job training leading to industry-recognized certificates. It also details how grants will be prioritized and used to support renewable energy job creation programs. Grants will be sufficient in size and last for 3 years, with funds used as specified by the State receiving the grant. The State receiving a grant must use the funds to reimburse employers for on-the-job training, provide skills training through various entities, and conduct outreach to inform eligible parties about the program. Under the pilot program, a State receiving a grant must repay any unused funds, submit reports to the Secretary, and ensure that individuals in on-the-job training are paid at least the minimum wage. Requirements for grant recipients under the pilot program include submitting an application to the State and quarterly reports to the Secretary. Administrative costs are limited to 2 percent for federal administration and determined by the Secretary for state administration. The Secretary determines the maximum grant amount for administrative costs. An annual report to Congress is required, detailing program activities and participant employment outcomes. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2015-2017. Definitions include "Indian tribe." The term "Indian tribe" is defined as per the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994. "Installed alternative energy power capacity" refers to the amount of wind, solar, and geothermal power generation in megawatts in a State. "Labor organization" is defined as per the National Labor Relations Act. "On-the-job training" is training provided by renewable energy and energy efficiency employers, labor organizations, educational institutions, or nonprofit organizations to paid participants for job performance. The term "postsecondary educational institution" is defined as per the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. A "renewable energy and energy efficiency employer" is an entity that employs individuals in the renewable energy and energy efficiency sector. The term "renewable energy and energy efficiency industries" encompass various sectors such as energy-efficient building, renewable electric power, and energy efficiency assessment. Skills training refers to essential job training provided by labor organizations, postsecondary educational institutions, or nonprofit organizations in these industries. The term "State" includes various states and territories of the United States. The term "workforce investment board" refers to a board established to coordinate job training programs under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 or its successor statute.
